channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Republicans Gain Edge as Voters Worry About Economy, Times/Siena Poll Finds
item.description: With elections next month, independents, especially women, are swinging to the G.O.P. despite Democrats’ focus on abortion rights. Disapproval of President Biden seems to be hurting his party.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: NYT/Siena Poll Is Latest to Show Republican Gains
item.description: Is four points the real margin nationally? That’s a good question.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The path to keeping the House and the Senate appears to be getting tougher for Democrats, according to the most recent polling. Campaign signs for the Ohio Democratic Senate candidate Tim Ryan in Columbus on Friday.

item.title: Jill Biden Ramps Up Visits to Democratic Midterm Campaigns
item.description: Requests for the first lady, who is also the president’s most popular surrogate, are piling up ahead of the midterm elections. Her visits can deliver a morale boost and a fund-raising opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Gerardo Mora/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jill Biden, center, appeared at a rally for Representative Val B. Demings, second from left, and Charlie Crist, second from right, on Saturday as part of a bustling weekend of events.

item.title: Warnock Hammers Walker in Senate Debate, Gesturing to an Empty Lectern
item.description: Herschel Walker did not join the debate, but Senator Raphael Warnock opted for direct attacks over the veiled criticisms he has used for most of his campaign.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: Ben Gray/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Libertarian candidate for Senate in Georgia, Chase Oliver, left, and Senator Raphael Warnock, the Democratic incumbent, debated alongside an empty lectern representing Herschel Walker, the Republican, on Sunday in Atlanta.

item.title: What We Know About the Iranian-Made Drones Russia Is Using in Ukraine
item.description: Russia has used the drones to strike on the battlefield and in Ukrainian cities. Their use may be a sign that Moscow is running low on precision-guided weapons.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedestrians walked past wreckage from an explosive drone attack in Kyive on Monday.

item.title: Russia’s Draft Sends Barely Trained Men to War in Ukraine
item.description: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts at army games in the Moscow region in August. Russia struggled with training even before September’s draft, experts said.

item.title: Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt Drops Most of U.K. Tax-Cut Plan
item.description: Jeremy Hunt also put a time limit on energy subsidies, seeking to reassure markets and reduce pressure on Prime Minister Liz Truss.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Neil Hall/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The statement by Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Jeremy Hunt, laid bare a government forced into a humiliating 180-degree turn in its economic policy.

item.title: Stock Markets Bounce After a Week of Whiplash
item.description: The S&P 500 rose sharply in early trading on Monday after strong earnings at Bank of America and news of a radically revised tax plan in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: ‘Moving Backward’: In Xi’s China, Some See an Era of Total Control
item.description: A decade ago, many prominent Chinese hoped that Xi Jinping would usher in openness and reform. Today, some of them believe he has created a totalitarian state.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Florence Lo/Reuters
item.media:description: An image of Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at a military museum in Beijing.

item.title: China Delays the Release of G.D.P. and Other Economic Data
item.description: The unusual move comes as the country’s ruling elite have gathered in Beijing for the twice-a-decade national congress of the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Delegates leaving the opening ceremony of the national congress of the Communist Party in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: In Xi’s China, the Business of Business Is State-Controlled
item.description: The Chinese leader has increasingly demanded that businesses conform to the aims of the Communist Party, an agenda he doubled down on this week at an important political gathering.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Chang Che and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, during his speech at the Communist Party congress in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: An Uptick in Elder Poverty: A Blip, or a Sign of Things to Come?
item.description: Seniors didn’t fare as well through the pandemic as most. But longer-term trends aren’t moving in their favor either.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Mike Belleme
item.media:description: Juanita Brown, 77, has had to do without things like replacing her dentures or replenishing her heating oil.

item.title: Fencing Can Be Six-Figure Expensive, but It Wins in College Admissions
item.description: How niche sports offer a pathway to the Ivy League and other elite schools.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Photographs by Desiree Rios
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Manhattan Fencing Center says the sport can help students distinguish themselves in applications.

item.title: Election Officials Prepare for New Challenges in Midterm Vote
item.description: Right-wing leaders are mobilizing a national corps of aggressive election activists. “We’re going to adjudicate every battle,” Stephen K. Bannon said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: An employee sorted boxes of mail-in ballots in Phoenix earlier this month.

item.title: The Problem of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: What the rise of the far-right congresswoman means for the House, the G.O.P. and the nation.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Stephen Voss for The New York Times

item.title: The Rise of Salem Media, a Conservative Radio Juggernaut
item.description: Salem Media, which counts the conservative personalities Charlie Kirk and Sebastian Gorka among its radio hosts, has taken a pointed stance ahead of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charlie Kirk, a conservative who hosts a radio show for Salem Media, at a political rally in August. He has joined a tour backed by Salem to promote his views and Republican candidates ahead of the midterm elections.

item.title: Justice Dept. Recommends Bannon Be Sentenced to 6 Months in Prison
item.description: Stephen K. Bannon, who is set to be sentenced on Friday, deserved a penalty harsher than the minimum term of one month in jail because he had blatantly brushed off the Jan. 6 committee’s demands, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon, a former top aide to President Donald J. Trump, is set to be sentenced on Friday.

item.title: Victor Wembanyama Has Always Done Things Differently
item.description: Wembanyama, an 18-year-old with an eight-foot wingspan, will almost certainly be the top pick in next year’s N.B.A. draft. He’s been preparing for the moment for years.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victor Wembanyama, a rising French basketball star, isn’t like anyone else. He’s 7-foot-3, but he’s as smooth as a smaller guard like Stephen Curry.

item.title: NBA Season Preview: The Nets and the Lakers Are the Wild Cards
item.description: Newly healthy stars and rising young players could shift the power dynamics in both conferences. But if the Nets and the Lakers can recover from off-season drama, they may be the teams to beat.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola, Sopan Deb, Tania Ganguli, Dorothy J. Gentry, Victor Mather and Kris Rhim
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Dakarai Akil; photographs via Getty Images

item.title: The Era of NFT Reservations and Paywalled Restaurants Is Upon Us
item.description: From private “clubstaurants” to NFT reservation tokens to concierge services, getting a table is a lot easier if you’ve got the money.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sugar
item.media:credit: Jonathan Carlson

item.title: How Much Will the Supreme Court Change the World?
item.description: Not to mention the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Grutter v. Bollinger’s affirmation of affirmative action may well be the next precedent to fall.

item.title: Putin’s Desperate Measures Won’t Get Him What He Wants
item.description: None of the Kremlin’s recent gambits are likely to change the battlefield dynamics.
item.dc:creator: Dara Massicot
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ramil Sitdikov/Sputnik

item.title: A New Playbook for Saving Democracy, Defeating Fascism and Winning Elections
item.description: In the longer contest to tell the better story about America and draw people into that story, there is a great worry among organizers that the left is badly falling short.
item.dc:creator: Anand Giridharadas
item.media:credit: Jon Han

item.title: Why We Should All Be Chasing Acorns
item.description: Oaks are keystone plants, the central life form upon which so many other species in the ecosystem depend.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Kristine Potter for The New York Times

item.title: Imagining a Post-Global World
item.description: The chaos that’s engulfed the economy is driven by a seismic shift toward a better balance between the global and the local.
item.dc:creator: Rana Foroohar
item.media:credit: Illustration by Jordan Awan for The New York Times; photographs by Javier Zayas Photography and dikobraziy, via Getty Images

item.title: How Liberals Should Confront a Right-Wing Supreme Court
item.description: The court does not have the only word, or even the last word, on the meaning of the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Fishkin and William E. Forbath
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; images by Robert Alexander via Getty Images

item.title: Wait, Who Did You Say Is Middle-Aged?
item.description: Boomers didn’t appreciate getting long in the tooth. But as a Gen Xer, I have to assume it’s worse for us.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Comeback
item.description: Republican leaders have embraced the former political pariah, demonstrating Trumpism’s hold over the party.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor-Greene.

item.title: The Personal and Political Saga of Herschel Walker
item.description: The Georgia Senate race has become increasingly focused on the private life and alleged hypocrisy of the Republican nominee.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Sydney Harper, Nina Feldman, Robert Jimison, Patricia Willens, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times; Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Raphael Warnock, left, and his opponent, Herschel Walker. Georgia was the closest state in the country in 2020: President Biden won there by just two-tenths of a point.

item.title: The Enduring Appeal of Ronaldo, Soccer’s Original Phenomenon
item.description: The Brazilian striker’s lasting power lies not so much in a deep trove of highlight clips, but in what he showed was possible.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: The Young Women Who Make TikTok Weep
item.description: Songwriters who have found success on the app via emotional catharsis have expanded its range, and piqued the music industry’s interest.
item.media:credit: Jaime Molina for The New York Times

item.title: Migrants in New York Are Grateful for Help. But They Want to Work.
item.description: Newly arrived asylum seekers are finding that their job options are limited by federal rules on work permits.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times
item.media:description: Genesis Chirino saw no future in her home country, Venezuela, where expenses were soaring and political freedoms were curtailed.

item.title: In Battle Against Trash and Rats, N.Y.C. Officials Try a Schedule Shift
item.description: New Yorkers will be asked to place trash on the curb later to reduce the amount of time that mountains of trash fester on the streets.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman picked cans and bottles from trash piled on the sidewalk over Downing Street, between Bedford Street and Sixth Avenue in Manhattan.

item.title: Charles Sherrod, Civil Rights Pioneer in Rural Georgia, Dies at 85
item.description: He brought his deep Christian faith and his commitment to grass-roots organizing to the small town of Albany. He never left.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Charles Sherrod at his home in Albany, Ga., in 2008. He was among the first Black leaders to grasp the importance of moving into a community, building ties with local leaders and developing a broad-based coalition.

item.title: Iran’s Loyal Security Forces Protect Ruling System That Protesters Want to Topple
item.description: The Revolutionary Guards — the country’s most powerful military force — have become so deeply woven into Iran’s economy and power structure that they have everything to lose if the system falls.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Ebrahim Noroozi/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Revolutionary Guards, a force with hundreds of thousands of members, is separate from the national army and is charged specifically with defending the ruling system.

item.title: 4 Ways to Boost Your Immune System Ahead of Cold and Flu Season
item.description: Here are four things immunologists and other health experts say you can do.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Cristina Spanò

item.title: Is Matcha Good for You?
item.description: The brightly colored powdered green tea has become popular among health-conscious consumers. Does it have any nutritional benefits?
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
item.description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
item.dc:creator: Emily Pennington
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Vuity Review: I Swapped My Reading Glasses for Magical Eyedrops
item.description: Vuity, taken daily, promises clear vision for up to 10 hours. But does it work?
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Desmond Picotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vuity, eyedrops that can help people see up close without affecting their long-range vision, went on the market in December.

item.title: A Pioneering Black Ballerina’s Life Story Comes to the Stage
item.description: Lauren Anderson, whose story is told in “Plumshuga” in Houston, talks about the show, her personal battles and storied career: “I got to the mountaintop.”
item.dc:creator: Kayla Stewart
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lauren Anderson hugs Danae McGlothen, the dancer who plays a young Lauren in “Plumshuga,” on opening night in Houston.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
